action.action-desc: Mr. Amash (for himself, Mr. Meadows, Mr. McClintock, Mr. McKinley, Mr. Cramer, Mr. Loudermilk, Mr. Massie, Mr. Huffman, Mr. Polis, Mr. Jones, Mr. Moulton, Mr. Messer, Ms. Norton, Mr. Brat, Mr. Tonko, Mr. Norman, and Mr. Khanna) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and in addition to the Committee on House Administration, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To require all bills, resolutions, and other documents of Congress to be created, transmitted, and published in searchable electronic formats, and for other purposes.

subsection.text: This Act may be cited as the Searchable Legislation Act of 2018.
The purposes of this Act are as follows:

paragraph.text: To establish nonproprietary, machine-readable data standards for the creation, transmission, and publication of Congressional information.

To encourage the uniform use of nonproprietary, machine-readable data standards, including searchable electronic formats, for Congressional information by Congress and its support agencies and offices.
To ensure that Congressional information, especially bills, resolutions, orders, and votes, can be freely downloaded in bulk and electronically searched.

section.header: Requiring searchable electronic formats for Congressional documents

paragraph.text: Chapter 2 of title 1, United States Code, is amended by inserting after section 107 the following new section:

section.text: To the greatest extent practicable, Congress shall ensure that all bills, resolutions, orders, and other documents of Congress, and all records of votes cast in Congress and committees of Congress, are created, transmitted, and published in searchable electronic formats, consistent with data standards recommended by such advisory bodies as Congress may establish.

paragraph.text: The table of sections for chapter 2 of title 1, United States Code, is amended by inserting after the item relating to section 107 the following new item:

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply with respect to the One Hundred Sixteenth Congress and each succeeding Congress.

Not later than 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate, acting jointly, shall establish an advisory body to be known as the Congressional Data Task Force (hereafter referred to as the Task Force).

paragraph.text: The Task Force shall recommend data standards for the creation, transmission, and publication of information and documents of Congress, including bills, resolutions, amendments, reports, laws, and records, in searchable electronic formats for purposes of section 107a of title 1, United States Code (as added by section 2(a)).
All data standards recommended by the Task Force shall be nonproprietary and machine-readable, and, to the greatest extent possible, shall enable the bulk downloading of information.
In carrying out its duties, the Task Force shall consult with private entities with expertise in data transparency standards.

The Task Force shall be composed of employee representatives of the Office of the Clerk of the House, the Office of the Secretary of the Senate, the Library of Congress, the Congressional Research Service, the Government Publishing Office, the Center for Legislative Archives, and such other offices of Congress and the legislative branch as the Clerk and Secretary consider appropriate.
Members of the Task Force may not receive additional pay, allowances, or benefits by reason of their service on the Task Force.

subsection.text: No additional funds may be appropriated to carry out this section during a fiscal year.
The Task Force shall terminate on the last day of the One Hundred Seventeenth Congress.
